citation.article-title: Proposal of Roseburia faecis sp. nov., Roseburia hominis sp. nov. and Roseburia inulinivorans sp. nov., based on isolates from human faeces.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Roseburia hominis sp. nov.
Roseburia hominis (hom.i′nis. L. gen. n. hominis, of a human being, referring to human gut habitat).
Cells are Gram-variable to Gram-negative, slightly curved rods, and motile by means of multiple flagella.
Good growth occurs on M2GSC agar at 37 °C and after incubation for 48 h forms creamy white translucent colonies with entire edges, approximately 1–3 mm in diameter.
Utilizes arabinose, fructose, glucose, maltose, cellobiose, xylose and glycerol as energy sources for growth.
Weak/no growth occurs with raffinose or melibiose as energy source.
Sucrose, sorbitol, oat spelt xylan, amylopectin starch and inulin (dahlia) are not utilized for growth.
Butyrate and formate are major products and lactate a minor product from glucose (0.2 %), with net consumption of acetate present in the medium.
The G+C content of the DNA of the type strain is 47.4 mol%.
Isolated from human faeces in Aberdeen, Scotland.
